What is the knowledge of others' minds?
Answer:

If knowledge is accomplished through cultivation, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and is able to know the present minds and mental factors of the desire and form realms, or the uncontaminated minds and mental factors of others' continuums, this is called:
The knowledge of others' minds.
What is the knowledge of recollecting past abodes?
Answer:

If knowledge is accomplished through cultivation, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and is able to recollect and know the various aspects and things said of past abodes,
This is called:
The knowledge of recollecting past abodes.
Do all knowledges of others' minds directly know the minds and mental factors of others?
Answer:
There are four possibilities.
There is knowledge of others' minds that is not the present knowledge of others' minds and mental factors.
This refers to:
The knowledge of others' minds in the past and future.
There is present knowledge of others' minds and mental factors that is not knowledge of others' minds.
This refers to:
For example, if one observes signs, hears speech, or obtains such knowledge through rebirth, one can presently know others' minds and mental factors.
There is knowledge of others' minds that is also the present knowledge of others' minds and mental factors.
This refers to:

If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and can presently know others' minds and mental factors in the present desire and form realms, or the uncontaminated mind and mental factors.
There is neither knowledge of others' minds nor the present knowledge of others' minds and mental factors.
This refers to:
Excluding the above characteristics.
Do all knowledges of past abodes recollect and know past events?
Answer:
There are four possibilities.
There is recollection of past abodes that is not the present recollection of past abodes.
This refers to:
The recollection of past abodes in the past and future.
There is the present recollection of past abodes that is not the recollection of past abodes.
This refers to:
As when one attains the knowledge of the nature of recollection of past lives, or attains the knowledge of the place of birth, one can presently recollect past abodes.
There is recollection of past abodes that is also the present recollection of past abodes.
This refers to:
If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and can presently recollect past abodes with various characteristics,
And what has been said.
There is that which is neither recollection of past abodes nor the present recollection of past abodes.
This refers to:
Excluding the above characteristics.
Do all recollections of past abodes know the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements of others' mind-continua?
Answer:
Four sentences should be made.
There is recollection of past lives that is not the knowledge of the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements of others' mind streams.
This refers to:

If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and knows one's own past aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and the mind stream of past lives.
There is the knowledge of the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements of others' mind streams, but it is not the recollection of past lives.
This refers to:

If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and knows the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements of others' mind stream in this life.
There is the recollection of past lives that is also the knowledge of the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements of others' mind streams.
This refers to:

If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, has been attained and not lost, and knows the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements, and the mind stream of others' past lives.
There is [knowledge] that is neither the knowledge of recollecting past abodes nor the knowledge of the mental continuums of others in the past aggregates, sense bases, and elements.
This refers to:

If the knowledge is cultivated, is the fruit of cultivation, is based on cultivation, and has been attained and not lost, it is the knowledge of one's own aggregates, sense bases, and elements in the present and past mental continuums.
What is the mind liberation of loving-kindness at the right time?
Answer:

The knowledge of cessation of an arhat who is temporarily liberated, or the mind of right view of the post-learner stage that is associated with [the knowledge of cessation], and the resolve, the already resolved, and the future resolve.
What is the immovable mind liberation?
Answer:

The knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of non-arising of an arhat who is immovable, or the mind of right view of the post-learner stage that is associated with [the two knowledges], and the resolve, the already resolved, and the future resolve.
Are all mind liberations of loving-kindness at the right time associated with the knowledge of cessation?
Answer:
One should make a four-part distinction.
Sometimes there is a mind liberation of loving-kindness that is not associated with the knowledge of cessation.
This refers to:

The minds of arhats liberated according to circumstances, and of those with right view in the stage of no-more-learning, are associated with resolve, have already been associated with resolve, and will be associated with resolve.
There is that which is associated with the knowledge of destruction, but not with the mind liberation of one free from passion at the proper time.
This refers to:
The minds of arhats of the immovable class, associated with the knowledge of destruction, are associated with resolve, have already been associated with resolve, and will be associated with resolve.
There is that which is the mind liberation of one free from passion at the proper time, and is also associated with the knowledge of destruction.
This refers to:

The minds of arhats liberated according to circumstances, associated with the knowledge of destruction, are associated with resolve, have already been associated with resolve, and will be associated with resolve.
There is that which is the mind liberation of one free from passion not at the proper time, and is also not associated with the knowledge of destruction.
This refers to:

The knowledge of non-arising of arhats of the immovable class, or the minds associated with right view in the stage of no-more-learning, are associated with resolve, have already been associated with resolve, and will be associated with resolve.
Are all immovable mind liberations associated with the knowledge of non-arising?
Answer:
All that is associated with the knowledge of non-arising is an immovable mind liberation.
There is unshakable liberation of mind that is not associated with the knowledge of non-arising.
This refers to:

The knowledge of destruction of an arhat of the unshakable type, or the mind of right view of the post-learner stage that is associated with it, which has been liberated, is being liberated, or will be liberated.
Why is the liberation of mind at the time called love?
Answer:
The arhat liberated at times always earnestly guards, cherishes, and holds this dharma, lest he lose it due to conditions.
Like a person with only one eye, he and his friends earnestly guard, cherish, and hold it, lest this one eye be further damaged by conditions such as cold, heat, dust, or haze.
It is the same for him, therefore it is called love.
What is learning and insight?
Answer:
Learning wisdom.
What is learning and knowledge?
Answer:
The eight knowledges of the learner.
What is post-learning and insight?
Answer:
Post-learning wisdom.
What is post-learning and knowledge?
Answer:
The eight knowledges of the post-learner.
At the time of the realization of the truths, which one attains the purity of faith first?
Is it the Buddha?
Is it the Dharma?
Is it the Saá¹…gha?
Answer:
At the time of the realization of suffering, origination, and cessation, one first attains the purity of faith in the Dharma.
At the time of the realization of the path, one first attains the purity of faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha.
How many of the four inversions have been eliminated by all stream-enterers?
How many have not been eliminated?
Answer:
All have been eliminated.
How many of the three concentrations on emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness have been accomplished by all stream-enterers in the past?
How many in the future?
How many in the present?
Answer:
In the future:
All.
In the past:
If they have already ceased without being lost.
In the present:
If they are present.
Have all past paths already been cultivated and already ceased?
Answer:
All past paths have already been cultivated and already ceased.
There are paths that have already been cultivated and have already ceased, but are not past.
This refers to:ğŸ”½paths that are future, and have already been cultivated and have already ceased.
Do all paths that are future not yet have cultivation and cessation?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are paths that are future, but not yet have cultivation and cessation.
This refers to:
paths that are future, and have already been cultivated and have already ceased.
There are paths that have not yet had cultivation and cessation, but are not future.
This refers to:
paths that have not yet been attained, and are first present.
There are paths that are future, and also have not yet had cultivation and cessation.
This refers to:ğŸ”½paths that are future, and have not yet had cultivation and cessation.
There are paths that are neither future, nor have not yet had cultivation and cessation.
This refers to:
paths that are past;
and paths that have been attained, and are now present.
All paths that are present are being cultivated.
There are paths that are being cultivated but are not present.
Namely,
the path that has not been attained before, when first present;
the future path that is being cultivated, of that type.
The eight knowledges encompass cultivation, characteristics, objects, conditions, cessation, and realization.
Knowledge, cognition, thought, seven wholesome [minds], this chapter wishes to fully explain.
There are eight knowledges.
Namely,
knowledge of dharmas up to knowledge of the path.
What is knowledge of dharmas?
Answer:
The uncontaminated knowledge regarding all formations, causes of formations, cessation of formations, and the path that can eliminate formations in the desire realm.
Moreover,
the uncontaminated knowledge regarding knowledge of dharmas and the stage of knowledge of dharmas is called
knowledge of dharmas.
What is inferential knowledge?
Answer:
The uncontaminated knowledge regarding all formations, causes of formations, cessation of formations, and the path that can eliminate formations in the form and formless realms.
Moreover,
The undefiled cognition that exists in the cognition of the subsequent class and the stage of the cognition of the subsequent class is called:
the cognition of the subsequent class.
What is cognition of others' minds?
Answer:
If cognition is the fruit of cultivation, it is the cognition of others' present mind and mental factors.
What is conventional cognition?
Answer:
The contaminated wisdom of the three realms.
What is cognition of suffering?
Answer:
The cognition that arises with the aspects of suffering, impermanence, emptiness, and non-self regarding formations.
What is cognition of the origin [of suffering]?
Answer:
The cognition that arises with the aspects of cause, origin, production, and condition regarding the cause of formations.
What is cognition of cessation?
Answer:
The cognition that arises with the aspects of cessation, tranquility, excellence, and separation regarding the cessation of formations.
What is cognition of the path?
Answer:
The cognition that arises with the aspects of path, truth, practice, and exit regarding the path that is the antidote to formations.
As for dharma cognition up to path cognition, how many of the eight cognitions do they each include?
Answer:
Dharma cognition includes dharma cognition and five minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Cognition of others' minds, cognition of suffering, cognition of accumulation, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
Inferential cognition includes inferential cognition and five minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Cognition of others' minds, cognition of suffering, cognition of accumulation, cognition of cessation, and cognition of the path.
Cognition of others' minds includes cognition of others' minds and four minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Dharma cognition, inferential cognition, conventional cognition, and cognition of the path.
Conventional cognition includes conventional cognition and a minor part of cognition of others' minds.
Cognition of suffering includes cognition of suffering and two minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Dharma cognition and inferential cognition.
Cognition of accumulation includes cognition of accumulation and two minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Dharma cognition and inferential cognition.
Cognition of cessation includes cognition of cessation and two minor parts of cognition.
Namely:
Dharma cognition and inferential cognition.
The path cognition includes the path cognitionâ€”â€”the three cognitions in part.
Namely:
the cognition of dharmas, the cognition of the aspects of the truths, and the cognition of others' minds.
If one possesses the cognition of dharmas, how many of these eight cognitions does one possess?
How many does one not possess?
Answer:
Either three, four, five, six, seven, or eight.
Namely:
At the time of the forbearance of the cognition of dharmas of suffering and the cognition of the aspects of the truths of suffering:
â€”â€”Without the cognition of others' minds, one possesses three.
If one possesses the cognition of others' minds, one possesses four.
At the time of the forbearance of the cognition of dharmas of accumulation and the cognition of dharmas:
â€”â€”Without the cognition of others' minds, one possesses four.
If one possesses the cognition of others' minds, one possesses five.
At the time of the forbearance of the cognition of dharmas of cessation up to the cognition of dharmas:
Without the cognition of others' minds, one possesses five.
If one possesses the cognition of others' minds, one possesses six.
At the time of the forbearance of the cognition of dharmas of the path up to the cognition of dharmas:
Without the cognition of others' minds, one possesses six.
If one possesses the cognition of others' minds, one possesses seven.
When attaining the knowledge of the path up to the knowledge of the aspects of the path:
- Without the knowledge of others' minds, one attains seven.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one attains eight.
If one attains the knowledge of the aspects, how many of these eight knowledges does one attain?
How many does one not attain?
Answer:
Either four, five, six, seven, or eight.
That is to say:
When the knowledge of the aspects of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the aspects of the origination arise:
- Without the knowledge of others' minds.
One attains four.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one attains five.
When the knowledge of the aspects of the origination up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the aspects of cessation arise:
Without the knowledge of others' minds.
One attains five.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one attains six.
When the knowledge of the aspects of cessation up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the aspects of the path arise:
Without the knowledge of others' minds.
One attains six.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one attains seven.
When attaining the knowledge of the path up to the knowledge of the aspects of the path:
- Without the knowledge of others' minds.
One attains seven.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses eight.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, how many of these eight knowledges does one possess?
How many does one not possess?
Answer:
Either two, four, five, six, seven, or eight.
This refers to ordinary beings and noble ones:
At the time of the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of suffering:
One possesses two.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the similarity of suffering:
One possesses four.
At the time of the knowledge of the similarity of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the origin:
One possesses five.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of the origin up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of cessation:
One possesses six.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of cessation up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path:
One possesses seven.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of the path up to the knowledge of the similarity of the path:
One possesses eight.
If one possesses conventional knowledge, how many of these eight knowledges does one possess?
How many does one not possess?
Answer:
Or one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, or eight.
That is to say, ordinary beings and noble ones:
At the time of the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of suffering:
â€”â€”Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses one.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses two.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the similarity of suffering:
â€”â€”Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses three.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses four.
At the time of the knowledge of the similarity of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the origin:
â€”â€”Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses four.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses five.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of the origin up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of cessation:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses five.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses six.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of cessation up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses six.
With the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
At the time of the knowledge of the factors of the path up to the knowledge of the similarity of the path:
If one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses eight.
If one possesses the knowledge of suffering, how many of these eight knowledges does one possess?
How many does one not possess?
Answer:
Either three, four, five, six, seven, or eight.
That is to say:
At the time of the knowledge of the truth of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the subsequent truth of suffering,
if one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses three.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses four.
At the time of the knowledge of the subsequent truth of suffering and the receptivity to the knowledge of the truth of accumulation,
if one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses four.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses five.
At the time of the knowledge of the truth of accumulation up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the truth of cessation,
if one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses five.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses six.
At the time of the knowledge of the truth of cessation up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the truth of the path,
if one does not possess the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses six.
If one possesses the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
When attaining the knowledge of the path up to the knowledge of the aspects of the path:
- If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one attains seven.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one attains eight.
If one attains the knowledge of the accumulation, how many of these eight knowledges does one attain?
How many does one not attain?
Answer:
Either five, six, seven, or eight.
That is to say:
When the knowledge of the dharmas of the accumulation up to the receptivity of the knowledge of the dharmas of cessation:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one attains five.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one attains six.
When the knowledge of the dharmas of cessation up to the receptivity of the knowledge of the dharmas of the path:
If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one attains six.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one attains seven.
When the knowledge of the dharmas of the path up to the knowledge of the aspects of the path:
- If one does not have the knowledge of others' minds, one attains seven.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one attains eight.
If one attains the knowledge of cessation, how many of these eight knowledges does one attain?
How many does one not attain?
Answer:
Either six, seven, or eight.
Namely:
When the knowledge of the cessation of dharmas up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the path of dharmas,
without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses six.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
When the knowledge of the path of dharmas up to the receptivity to the knowledge of the class of the path,
without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses eight.
If one possesses the knowledge of the path, how many of these eight knowledges does one possess?
How many does one not possess?
The answer is:
Either seven or eight.
Namely:
Without the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses seven.
If one has the knowledge of others' minds, one possesses eight.
If one cultivates the knowledge of dharmas, does one also cultivate the knowledge of classes?
The answer is:
Four sentences should be made.
There is cultivation of the knowledge of dharmas but not the knowledge of classes.
Namely:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path.
When the knowledge of dharmas already attained is present for the arhat who has seen the traces of learning.
There is cultivation of the knowledge of classes but not the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely:
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation, and the subsequent knowledge of the truth of the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner, or an arhat, has already attained the subsequent knowledge and it is presently manifest.
There are cases where both are cultivated.
Namely,
when entering the realization of the truth of the path and the subsequent knowledge of the truth of the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner, or an arhat, has not yet attained a pure cognition and it is presently manifest.
When not yet having attained a conventional cognition and it is presently manifest, and both are cultivated at the same time.
There are cases where neither are cultivated.
Namely,
when a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner, or an arhat, has already attained a conventional cognition and it is presently manifest.
When not yet having attained a conventional cognition and it is presently manifest, and neither are cultivated at the same time.

When all ordinary beings, with defiled minds, indeterminate minds, in the attainment of non-perception, in the attainment of cessation, in the heavens of non-perception, and when not yet having attained pure acceptance.
If one cultivates cognition of dharmas, does one also cultivate cognition of others' minds?
The answer is:
One should make four alternatives.
There are cases where one cultivates cognition of dharmas but not cognition of others' minds.
Namely,
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and path, and the knowledge of dharmas.
When one who is not yet free from the defilements of the desire realm enters the realization of the knowledge of the categories of the path.
When a learner who has seen the truths and an arhat who has already attained the knowledge of dharmas has it present, but not the knowledge of others' minds.
When one who has not yet attained the uncontaminated knowledge has it present, but does not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds.
When one who has not yet attained the conventional knowledge has it present, and cultivates the knowledge of dharmas, but not the knowledge of others' minds.
There is cultivation of the knowledge of others' minds, but not the knowledge of dharmas.
This refers to:
When ordinary beings who have already attained or have not yet attained the knowledge of others' minds have it present.
When one who has not yet attained the conventional knowledge has it present, and cultivates the knowledge of others' minds.
When a learner who has seen the truths and an arhat who has already attained the knowledge of others' minds have it present, but not the knowledge of dharmas.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When one who is already free from the defilements of the desire realm enters the realization of the knowledge of the categories of the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the knowledge of dharmas and it is present, and it is the knowledge of others' minds.
When one who has not yet attained the uncontaminated knowledge has it present, and one cultivates the knowledge of others' minds.
When one who has not yet attained the conventional knowledge has it present, and one is able to cultivate both [the knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of others' minds] together.
There are cases where both are not cultivated.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering, accumulation, and cessation, and the subsequent knowledge of the path.

When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the uncontaminated knowledge and it is present, but it is neither the knowledge of dharmas nor the knowledge of others' minds.
When one has already attained the conventional knowledge and it is present, but it is not the knowledge of others' minds.
When one who has not yet attained the conventional knowledge has it present, and one does not cultivate both [the knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of others' minds] together.
When ordinary beings do not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds.
In all defiled minds, indeterminate minds, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the non-percipient celestials, and the acceptance of the uncontaminated.
If one cultivates the knowledge of dharmas, does one also cultivate conventional knowledge?
The answer is:
One should make four statements.
There is cultivation of Dharma knowledge but not of conventional knowledge.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and path through Dharma knowledge, and when entering the realization of the path through subsequent knowledge.
When a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner or an arhat, who has already attained Dharma knowledge, has it present before them.
When one who has not yet attained undefiled knowledge has it present before them, but does not cultivate conventional knowledge.
There is cultivation of conventional knowledge but not of Dharma knowledge.
This refers to:
When ordinary beings, who have already attained or not yet attained conventional knowledge, have it present before them.
When entering the realization of the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation through subsequent knowledge.
When a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner or an arhat, who has already attained conventional knowledge, has it present before them.
When one who has not yet attained conventional knowledge has it present before them, but does not cultivate Dharma knowledge.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When a learner who has attained the state of a non-returner or an arhat, who has not yet attained undefiled knowledge, has it present before them, and cultivates conventional knowledge.
When one who has not yet attained conventional knowledge has it present before them, and cultivates Dharma knowledge.
There is cultivation of neither.
Namely:
When a learner who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat have already attained the present direct realization of the uncontaminated cognition, but not the cognition of dharmas.
All defiled minds, indeterminate minds, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the non-perceptual beings, and the uncontaminated acceptance.
If one cultivates the cognition of dharmas, does one also cultivate the cognition of suffering?
The answer is:
One should make four alternatives.
There is cultivation of the cognition of dharmas, but not the cognition of suffering.
Namely:
When entering the present direct realization of the cognition of dharmas of the aggregates, cessation, and path.
When a learner who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat have already attained the present direct realization of the cognition of dharmas, but not the cognition of suffering.
There is cultivation of the cognition of suffering, but not the cognition of dharmas.
Namely:
When entering the present direct realization of the cognition of the class of suffering.
When a learner who has attained the stage of insight and an arhat have already attained the present direct realization of the cognition of suffering, but not the cognition of dharmas.
There is cultivation of both.
Namely:
When entering the present direct realization of the cognition of dharmas of suffering and the cognition of the class of the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing and it is present,
when a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has not yet attained the uncontaminated knowledge and it is present,
when a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has not yet attained the conventional knowledge and it is present, and they are able to cultivate both [types of knowledge] at the same time.
There are cases where both are not cultivated.
This refers to:
when entering the realization of the knowledge of the aggregates, cessation, and species,

when a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the uncontaminated knowledge and it is present, but it is not the knowledge of the factors or the knowledge of suffering,
when a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has already attained the conventional knowledge and it is present,

when a learner who has attained the state of post-learner has not yet attained the conventional knowledge and it is present, but they do not cultivate the knowledge of the factors or the knowledge of suffering,

when all ordinary beings, defiled minds, indeterminate minds, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the non-percipient celestials, and the forbearance of the uncontaminated are present.
If one cultivates the knowledge of the factors, does one also cultivate the knowledge of the aggregates?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are cases where one cultivates the knowledge of the factors but does not cultivate the knowledge of the aggregates.
This refers to:
when entering the realization of the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing of suffering, cessation, and the path,
A learner who has attained the state of post-learner and has attained the knowledge of dharmas but not the knowledge of arising is present.
There is cultivation of the knowledge of arising but not the knowledge of dharmas.
This is when
one enters the realization of the knowledge of the class of arising.
A learner who has attained the state of post-learner and has attained the knowledge of arising but not the knowledge of dharmas is present.
There is cultivation of both.
This is whenğŸ”½one enters the realization of the knowledge of dharmas of arising and the knowledge of the class of the path.
A learner who has attained the state of post-learner and has attained the knowledge of dharmas and arising is present.
When one who has not yet attained the undefiled knowledge is present.
When one who has not yet attained the worldly knowledge is present, cultivating the knowledge of dharmas and arising.
There is no cultivation of both.
This is when
one enters the realization of the knowledge of the class of cessation and the path.
A learner who has attained the state of post-learner and has attained the undefiled knowledge but not the knowledge of dharmas and arising is present.
When one who has attained the worldly knowledge is present.
When not yet attained, worldly cognition does not presently manifest, and one does not cultivate cognition of dharmas and cognition of the origin.

All ordinary beings, in defiled minds, indeterminate minds, in the attainment of non-perception, in the attainment of cessation, in the heavens of non-perception, and in the forbearance of the unconditioned.

If one cultivates conventional knowledge, does one also cultivate the knowledge of cessation?
Answer:
One should make four alternatives.
There is the cultivation of conventional knowledge but not the knowledge of cessation.
This refers to:
When ordinary beings have already attained or have not yet attained conventional knowledge and it is present,
when entering the realization of the truths of suffering and accumulation and the knowledge of their categories,
when the arhat who has seen the traces of the training has already attained conventional knowledge and it is present,
when conventional knowledge that has not yet been attained is present but the knowledge of cessation is not cultivated.
There is the cultivation of the knowledge of cessation but not conventional knowledge.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the truth of cessation and the knowledge of the categories of the path,
when the arhat who has seen the traces of the training has already attained the knowledge of cessation and it is present,
when pure knowledge that has not yet been attained is present but conventional knowledge is not cultivated.
There is the cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of the extinction of the contaminants.
When a learner who has attained the state of being a post-learner or an arhat, who has not yet attained pure knowledge, has a mundane knowledge present and cultivates it.
When one who has not yet attained mundane knowledge has a mundane knowledge present and cultivates the knowledge of extinction.
There are cases where neither are cultivated.
Namely:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas regarding suffering, accumulation, and the path.
When a learner who has attained the state of being a post-learner or an arhat has a pure knowledge present but not the knowledge of extinction.
All defiled minds, indeterminate minds, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the non-percipient celestials, and the forbearance of the absence of the contaminants.
If one cultivates mundane knowledge, does one also cultivate the knowledge of the path?
Answer:
One should make four statements.
There are those who cultivate mundane knowledge but not the knowledge of the path.
Namely:
When ordinary beings who have already attained or have not yet attained mundane knowledge have it present.
When entering the realization of the knowledge of the aggregates, extinction, and the class of the knowledge of the path regarding suffering.
When a learner who has attained the state of being a post-learner or an arhat has mundane knowledge present.
When one who has not yet attained conventional knowledge manifests it, one does not cultivate the knowledge of the path.
There is cultivation of the knowledge of the path but not of conventional knowledge.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas and subsequent knowledge of the path.
When a learner who has seen the truths and an arhat who has already attained the knowledge of the path manifest it.
When one who has not yet attained pure knowledge manifests it, one does not cultivate conventional knowledge.
There is cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When a learner who has seen the truths and an arhat who has already attained pure knowledge manifest it and cultivate conventional knowledge.
When one who has not yet attained conventional knowledge manifests it and cultivates the knowledge of the path.
There is no cultivation of both.
This refers to:
When entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas of suffering, accumulation, and cessation.
When a learner who has seen the truths and an arhat who has already attained pure knowledge manifest it but not the knowledge of the path.
